p: Maceration is the oldest of the solidâ€“liquid extraction methods and is characterized by the simplicity and low cost of the procedure, as well as by the long duration needed for the achievement of an equilibrium concentration of the extracted metabolite in the solvent [ 25]. The use of glycerol for maceration of phenolic secondary metabolites is relatively rare [ 11, 26]. Bergeron et al. used glycerol for maceration of E. purpurea [ 27], but detailed and focused reports on the influence of glycerolic extraction conditions and comparisons with ethanol are still lacking.
